styleGuide.purpose: Dieses JSON-Dokument liefert standardisierte Hinweise und konkrete Korrekturvorschläge, um Manuskriptteile genderkonform, leicht affirmierend und wissenschaftlich konsistent zu gestalten. Ideal für E-Paper und akademische Veröffentlichungen.
styleGuide.usage: Für jede Textpassage: „section“ identifiziert den Kapitel- oder Absatzkontext, „original“ enthält den ursprünglichen Wortlaut, „issue“ beschreibt die Gender-Problematik, „suggestion“ gibt die korrigierte, affirmativ-gendergerechte Formulierung wieder.
principles: Verwende inklusive Formulierungen statt binärer Sprachmuster (z. B. „Teilnehmende“ statt „Teilnehmer“).
Vermeide Annahmen über Geschlechtsidentitäten; nutze neutrale oder mehrfach genannte Pronomen, wenn die Information nicht bekannt ist.
Setze Affirmationssprache ein (z. B. „Personen, die sich als … identifizieren“ statt „Transsexuelle“ ohne Kontext).
Formuliere Personenbezeichnungen in einer Weise, die nicht impliziert, dass nur zwei Geschlechter existieren.
Nutze neutrale Berufs- und Rollenbezeichnungen (z. B. „Studierende“ statt „Studenten“).

corrections.original: the Gender Congruence and Life Satisfaction Scale (GCLS) is a validated measure assessing outcomes in transgender and gender diverse individuals
corrections.issue: „transgender and gender diverse individuals“ ist korrekt, aber es fehlt eine affirmation und geschlechtsneutrale Anrede.
corrections.suggestion: the Gender Congruence and Life Satisfaction Scale (GCLS) is a validated measure assessing outcomes in Trans and Gender-Diverse People

corrections.original: A German version is needed to facilitate assessment and research in German-speaking healthcare settings.
corrections.issue: neutral, aber kann affirmativer gestaltet werden
corrections.suggestion: A German version is needed to facilitate inclusive assessment and research in German-speaking healthcare settings.

corrections.original: Despite increasing social visibility and media attention for transgender individuals, there remains a notable scarcity of validated instruments for assessing gender congruence specifically developed for transgender people in German-speaking regions.
corrections.issue: zweimalige Nennung von „transgender“ wirkt redundant; „transgender individuals“ und „transgender people“ kann zusammengefasst werden
corrections.suggestion: Despite increasing social visibility and media attention for Trans and Gender-Diverse People, there remains a notable scarcity of validated instruments for assessing gender congruence specifically developed for that community in German-speaking regions.

corrections.original: Current measurement tools, such as the Utrecht Gender Dysphoria Scale (Cohen-Kettenis & van Goozen, 1997) and the Hamburg Body Drawing Scale (Becker et al., 2016), are based on a binary understanding of gender, failing to reflect the growing diversity among transgender identities.
corrections.issue: betont binäres Verständnis, könnte affirmativer kontrastieren
corrections.suggestion: Existing measurement tools, such as the Utrecht Gender Dysphoria Scale (Cohen-Kettenis & van Goozen, 1997) and the Hamburg Body Drawing Scale (Becker et al., 2016), reflect a binary understanding of gender and do not encompass the richness of Trans and Gender-Diverse experiences.

corrections.original: We recruited 293 transgender individuals (average age = 39.8 years, SD = 16.4). The sample consisted of 44.3% trans feminine, 33.3% non-binary (including intersex), 16.7% trans masculine, and 4.6% other gender identities.
corrections.issue: „transgender individuals“ kann durch „Trans and Gender-Diverse People“ ersetzt werden, um affirmativer zu wirken. Außerdem sollte Einheitlichkeit bei Kategorien erreicht werden („trans feminine“ → „Trans Feminine Persons“)
corrections.suggestion: We recruited 293 Trans and Gender-Diverse People (average age = 39.8 years, SD = 16.4), including 44.3 % Trans Feminine, 33.3 % Non-Binary (including Intersex), 16.7 % Trans Masculine, and 4.6 % other gender identities.

corrections.original: The GCLS, originally developed and validated in English by Jones et al. (2019), is a comprehensive 38-item self-report measure designed specifically for transgender and gender diverse populations.
corrections.issue: zweimal „transgender and gender diverse“; kann verkürzt und affirmativer formuliert werden
corrections.suggestion: The GCLS, originally developed and validated in English by Jones et al. (2019), is a comprehensive 38-item self-report measure designed specifically for Trans and Gender-Diverse Populations.

corrections.original: Independent back-translation and review by the original authors helped ensure conceptual equivalence while identifying areas requiring cultural adaptation (Ozolins et al., 2020).
corrections.issue: neutral, nur leichte Affirmation hinzufügen
corrections.suggestion: Independent back-translation and review by the original authors ensured conceptual continuity and cultural sensitivity (Ozolins et al., 2020).

corrections.original: The sample showed a balanced distribution across gender identity groups, with Female AMAB participants comprising the largest group.
corrections.issue: „Female AMAB participants“ kann ergänzt werden zu „Trans Feminine (AMAB)“ für mehr Klarheit und Konsistenz
corrections.suggestion: The sample showed a balanced distribution across gender identity groups, with Trans Feminine (AMAB) participants comprising the largest group.

corrections.section: Results – Gender Identity and Transition Characteristics
corrections.original: Analysis of gender identity development timelines revealed comparable patterns across groups. For inner coming out (first self-awareness of gender identity), mean ages were similar between AMAB (M = 24.8 years, SD = 12.3) and AFAB participants (M = 22.9 years, SD = 11.8), t(289) = 1.32, p = .189.
corrections.issue: Verkürzung und Bezeichner klarer: AMAB → Trans Feminine (AMAB), AFAB → Trans Masculine (AFAB)
corrections.suggestion: Analysis of gender identity development timelines revealed comparable patterns across groups. For inner coming out (first self-awareness of gender identity), mean ages were similar between Trans Feminine (AMAB; M = 24.8 years, SD = 12.3) and Trans Masculine (AFAB; M = 22.9 years, SD = 11.8) participants (t(289) = 1.32, p = .189).

corrections.original: AMAB participants showed high utilization of feminizing interventions, with nearly universal estrogen therapy (97.3%) and frequent use of anti-androgens (70.1%).
corrections.issue: Bezeichnung „feminizing interventions“ → „feminizing gender-affirming interventions“ (genauer, affirmierend)
corrections.suggestion: AMAB participants showed high utilization of feminizing gender-affirming interventions, with nearly universal estrogen therapy (97.3 %) and frequent use of anti-androgens (70.1 %).

corrections.original: AFAB participants demonstrated similarly high rates of masculinizing interventions, with 96.8% using testosterone therapy and 86.2% having undergone chest masculinization surgery.
corrections.issue: Bezeichnung „masculinizing interventions“ → „masculinizing gender-affirming interventions“
corrections.suggestion: AFAB participants demonstrated similarly high rates of masculinizing gender-affirming interventions, with 96.8 % using testosterone therapy and 86.2 % having undergone chest masculinization surgery.

corrections.original: The data-driven EFA using maximum likelihood estimation with oblique rotation yielded a seven-factor solution, demonstrating good model fit (RMSEA = 0.054, 90% CI [0.048, 0.060]; TLI = 0.907; BIC = -1639.34).
corrections.issue: „data-driven EFA“ → „exploratory factor analysis (EFA)“ (Standardbegriff), CI in English belassen
corrections.suggestion: The exploratory factor analysis (EFA) using maximum-likelihood estimation with oblique rotation yielded a seven-factor solution, demonstrating good model fit (RMSEA = 0.054, 90 % CI [0.048, 0.060]; TLI = 0.907; BIC = –1639.34).

corrections.original: Factor loadings ≥ .40 were considered substantial for factor interpretation, with cross-loadings < .30 supporting simple structure.
corrections.issue: substantially → „significant primary loadings“ präzisieren
corrections.suggestion: Factor loadings ≥ 0.40 were considered significant primary loadings for interpretation, and cross-loadings < 0.30 supported a simple structure.

corrections.original: The ESEM analysis of the total sample (N = 293) revealed a robust seven-factor structure with excellent model fit (RMSEA = 0.054, 90% CI [0.048, 0.060]; TLI = 0.907; CFI = 0.923).
corrections.issue: „revealed a robust seven-factor structure“ → prägnanter: „confirmed the seven-factor structure“
corrections.suggestion: The ESEM analysis of the total sample (N = 293) confirmed the seven-factor structure with excellent model fit (RMSEA = 0.054, 90 % CI [0.048, 0.060]; TLI = 0.907; CFI = 0.923).

corrections.original: Convergent validity was robustly demonstrated through substantial negative correlations between GCLS-G subscales and conceptually related measures.
corrections.issue: „robustly demonstrated“ → prägnant „strongly supported“
corrections.suggestion: Convergent validity was strongly supported by substantial negative correlations between GCLS-G subscales and conceptually related measures.

corrections.original: The model fit indices demonstrated remarkable stability across the three subsamples.
corrections.issue: „remarkable stability“ kann wissenschaftlicher klingen: „high stability“
corrections.suggestion: The model fit indices demonstrated high stability across the three subsamples.

corrections.original: To evaluate known-groups validity, we compared GCLS subscale scores between AMAB and AFAB participants using Mann-Whitney U tests, as these groups are expected to show different patterns of gender congruence difficulties based on biological and social factors.
corrections.issue: Präzisere Terminologie: AMAB → Trans Feminine (AMAB), AFAB → Trans Masculine (AFAB).
corrections.suggestion: To evaluate known-groups validity, we compared GCLS subscale scores between Trans Feminine (AMAB) and Trans Masculine (AFAB) participants using Mann-Whitney U tests, as these groups may exhibit different patterns of gender-congruence difficulties based on biological and social factors.

corrections.original: The German version of the GCLS demonstrates strong psychometric properties and can be recommended for use in clinical practice and research with German-speaking transgender and gender diverse populations.
corrections.issue: „German-speaking transgender and gender diverse populations“ → affirmativer: „Trans and Gender-Diverse Communities in German-speaking regions“
corrections.suggestion: The German version of the GCLS demonstrates strong psychometric properties and can be recommended for use in clinical practice and research with Trans and Gender-Diverse Communities in German-speaking regions.

corrections.original: Participant
corrections.issue: Geschlechtsneutrale Form verwenden
corrections.suggestion: Participant → Participant/a oder Person (je nach Kontext)

corrections.original: he/she
corrections.issue: Nicht inklusiv, ersetzt durch neutrale Pronomen
corrections.suggestion: he/she → they
